Onesmus, a determined 26-year-old single businessman, has been selling milk to earn a living for the last two years, using his wheelbarrow to transport crates of milk to his customers. He has two employees to assist him, and he makes an extra shilling through farming.

With a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings, Onesmus wants to buy a new wheelbarrow and more milk. Within the next 5 years, he hopes to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: to buy a wheelbarrow and milk.

loans.name: Hasifah's Group

texts.en:
Hasifah, age 20, is a vegetable vendor who lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children. For the past eight years, Hasifah has been working hard to manage her vegetable stall. 

To help expand her business, Hasifah has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more vegetables to offer for sale, and it will help Hasifah to generate greater profits, wbich will allow her to start selling charcoal as well. Hasifah hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business more. 

Hasifah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Hasifah's future prospects by helping her to iincrease her capital. 

Hasifah's group is comprised of two hard-working women.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to offer for sale

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma, a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school, owns a house that has both electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children.

For the past two years, Mwanajuma has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbours and restaurant operators. She faces a major challenge of theft because of insecurity in her place of operation, and she dreams of establishing a shop to sell her products in the future.

Having decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business, with the loan of Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of beans and maize flour for her food stall.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of beans and maize flour for her food stall.

loans.name: Jackie

texts.en:
Jackie, a 30-year-old married mother of one child who is currently in school, lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. For the past five years, Jackie has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells pesticides, fertilizers and other farming supplies.

To help expand her business, Jackie has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase seeds and other farming supplies for resale, purchases that will help her to generate greater profits and impove her quality of life. She hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a wholesale soap shop and become one of the biggest suppliers in her area.

Jackie is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jackie who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and other farming supplies for resale.

loans.name: Oyuntungalag

texts.en:
Oyuntungalag is 45 years old and lives with her 23-year-old son and  her husband in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. The family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in an outer ger district (district without basic infrastructure) of the city. Her son works at a local company while his father works as a security worker. 

Oyuntungalag is very experienced in business.  Since 1997, she has been operating a clothing retail stall at the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. In 2003, she owned her rental stall and today her working capital is approximately two million MNT(Mongolian Tugriks).  Usually, she imports her products from Ereen, a border city between Mongolia and China. 

She requesting a 1,200,000 MNT  loan to purchase more clothes to sell at her stall this autumn. In the future, she wants to expand her business.  She is very thankful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon is a determined businessman, aged 82, and married. For the last ten years, he has been practicing poultry farming to earn a living. He also does dairy farming for extra income. He has retained his business because of his good reputation with his customers. In the next 5 years, he wants to distribute chicken to big hotels. He is requesting a loan of 100,000 Kenya shillings to buy chick mash.

loans.use: To buy chick mash

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a married woman with two school  aged children. She has a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

She has operated a vegetable grocery for the past five years.  Her potential clients are her neighbors and passers by. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation of commodities in the market. She dreams of expanding her business into a retail shop.

With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to purchase vegetables and fruits for her business. She decided to join Yehu to get capital for her business.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and fruits for her business.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a single woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past four years, she has operated a shoe business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. Halima dreams of establishing a stall to sell her products in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of shoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of shoes for resale.

loans.name: Lucie

texts.en:
Lucie is 31 years old and is married, with three children between 2 and 6 years old.  Lucie owns a business selling second-hand clothing. This is her seventh successful year in this business.  The hours of her business are from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day except on Sunday and she currently employs 3 people to help her. 

Lucie has requested a Kiva loan, via Vision Finance Company, in order to increase her second-hand business. With any profits, she will be able to build a secure future for her business as well as for her family and she will be able to renovate her house.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.fr:
Monsieur Ibrahima  vit au Sénégal. Il est âgé de 30 ans et il et animateur social depuis plus de 10 ans. Il a choisi son  activité par passion. Ibrahima est un soutien de famille  qui   est membre d’un des guichets de l’U-IMCEC depuis 6 ans .
 Ill sollicite un crédit de 200 000 frs prévu pour participer a  la construction de la clôture  de  la maison familiale.  Ce financement  peut contribuer à l’amélioration du cadre de vie d’une famille toute  entière.
texts.en:
Monsieur Ibrahima  lives in Sénégal. He is 30 years old and he has been working as a community organizer for more than 10 years. He chose his work out of enthusiasm for it. Ibrahima helps support his family and has been a member of a branch of U-IMCEC for six years. 

He is requesting a loan of 200,000 francs to help build a fence around his family home. This loan will contribute to improving the well-being of a whole family.

loans.use: to contribute toward building a fence around the family home.

loans.name: Ngoura

texts.fr: L'emprunteur est un homme marié, père de quatre enfants.Il exerce l'activité d'élevage en achetant des bovins qu'il engraisse pendant trois à quatre mois avant de les revendre.Son activité lui procure des revenus assez consistants pour prendre en charge sa famille. A l'approche des fete de Tabaski, il sollicite un pret de 200000F pour acheter un bœuf.
texts.en: The borrower is a married man, father of four children. He raises livestock, buying cattle that he fattens for four months before reselling them. His business brings in enough consistent income to support his family. As Tabaski (local name for a Muslim feast day) nears, he is requesting a loan of 200,000 francs to buy a cow.

loans.use: to buy a cow.

loans.name: Juan Bautista

texts.es:
El Señor Juan está casado con la Sra Nidia, tienen 2 hijos mayores casados e independiente de ellos. Tienen un negocio de compostura de calzado y venta de zapatos usados.
Se iniciaron en la actividad con un dinero que recibió Juan como parte de una indemnización que había recibido en un trabajo que realizo anteriormente. El manifiesta que la única forma de crecimiento es a través de los créditos, porque  resulta muy difícil conseguir acumular el capital operativo, razón por el cual opta por este pedido. El es una persona muy responsable y con ganas de superación, tiene un espíritu jovial y emprendedor que no cabe duda que vaya a llegar a conseguir todas las metas que se ha propuesto.
El solicita el crédito para la compra de calzados usados para la posterior venta. Agradece a la fundación por la oportunidad que esta le da.
texts.en:
Juan is married to Ms. Nidia. They have two older, married children who are independent. They have a business together where they repair shoes and sell used shoes.

They started the business with money that Juan received as compensation from an earlier job. He explains that the only way for him to grow is through loans, as it is very difficult to accumulate enough operating capital. This is why he opted to make this request. Juan is a very responsible person with a desire to improve his lot. He has a jovial spirit and is an entrepreneur who does not doubt that he is going to achieve all of the goals he has set for himself.

Juan is requesting this loan to buy used shoes that he will later resell. He is grateful to the foundation for this opportunity.

loans.use: to buy used shoes to resell

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 38 years old and lives in the town of Nyando in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children, 3 of them currently in school. For the past 6 years, Moses has been working hard to manage his small shop, which sells second-hand clothes. 

To help expand his business, Moses has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more bundles of second-hand clothes from the market, and will help Moses to generate greater profits, pay medical expenses, and start building a house. Moses hopes that in the future he will be able to continue to grow his business and perhaps start another side business. 

Moses is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Moses who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more bundles of second-hand clothes from the market

loans.name: Bathsheba

texts.en: Bathsheba is married with three children, all of whom attend school. For the last one year, she has been managing a greengrocer to support the family. She has employed one person to assist her in her tasks. In the next 5 years, she wants to expand her business. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy fruits and vegetables to increase her income.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is 46 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She is single and has 2 children. For the past 10 years, Veronica has been working hard to manage her garments shop, which sells clothing and other merchandise. 

To help expand her business, Veronica has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more materials to make clothes, and will help Veronica to generate greater profits and provide for her family's basic needs. Veronica hopes that in the future she will be able to afford having a house, built for her and her family. 

Veronica is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Veronica who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more materials to make clothes

loans.name: Benard

texts.en: Benard is a hardworking business man, aged 35. He is married and blessed with one child who is still in school. For the last two years, he has been managing a cafeteria to make a living. He has improved his business since he joined Faulu Kenya.  In the next 5 years, he wants to buy a piece of land. He is requesting a loan of 30,000 KES to buy ingredients such as cooking fat and wheat flour.

loans.use: To buy ingredients, such as cooking fat and wheat flour

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy one cow.

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea is 49 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala South region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children, 4 of whom are currently in school. For the past 18 years, Andrea has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells food and home supplies. 

To help expand his business, Andrea has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food to sell in his shop, and will help Andrea to generate greater profits and increase his family's income enough to pay the bills. Andrea hopes that in the future he will be able to finish building his house, to have a successful business, and to set up rental houses. 

Andrea is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Andrea who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more food to sell in his shop

loans.name: Abubakar

texts.en:
Abubakar is a married man with three children, two of whom attend school while one is too young for school. His wife is a businesswoman who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs.  Abubakar has a house with electricity and piped water.  His greatest monthly expense is food for his family. 

He has operated as a milk dealer for the past ten years.  In addition, he owns a garage. His potential clients are the people from the town. He faces a major challenge of customers buying goods on credit and taking too long to pay back. He dreams of expanding his business.

With the Kshs 80,000 he wants to purchase milk and a compressor machine for his business. He decided to join Yehu because of easy accessibility of loan facilities.

loans.use: To purchase milk and a compressor machine for his business.

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista is 21 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past 3 years, Teopista has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Teopista has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more sugar and soap for resale, and will help Teopista to generate greater profits and send her daughter to school. Teopista hopes that in the future she will be able to become a wholesaler. 

Teopista is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Teopista's future prospects by teaching her financial literacy.

loans.use: to buy more sugar and soap for resale

loans.name: Peterson

texts.en: Peterson is a focused businessman and is single. For the past year, he has been selling clothes to earn a living.  He has grown his business and thus improved his living standards.  He has managed to retain his business because of his good reputation with his customers.  In the next 5 years, he wants to expand his business. With the 20,000 Kenya shillings, he wants to buy clothes for resale.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Altantuya

texts.en:
Altantuya is 27-years-old and the young mother of two children ages 2 and 7. She lives with her family on a relative's land plot which is located in outer ger district, a district without basic infrastructure, in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her children attend a local secondary school and a kindergarten while their father works at a company. 

Since 2004, she has been operating a clothing retail stall business at the largest outdoor market in Mongolia by renting a small stall. Today, she owns a small stall and her working capital is about three million MNT /Mongolian Tugriks. She imports her products from Ereen, a border city between Mongolia and China once a month. 

She wants to improve her business and to increase her working capital so Altantuya is requesting a 2.000.000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes to sell from her stall and to increase her working capital as well. In the future she is planning to buy a small yard to build a new house there.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is 17-years-old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 2 years Patricia has been working hard to manage her boutique shop, where she sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Patricia has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for resale and will help Patricia to generate greater profits and expand her business and take care of her family. Patricia hopes that in the future she will be able to pay school fees for her young siblings. 

Patricia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Patricia's future prospects by teaching her life planning skills.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 30-years old and lives in the town of Pakwach in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married and has two children. For the past 16 years Stephen has been working hard to manage his retail shop where he sells snacks and common household items. 

To help expand his business, Stephen has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food to sell in his shop and will help Stephen to generate greater profits, pay medical expenses, buy land and build a house. Stephen hopes that in the future he will be able to start another side business. 

Stephen is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Stephen who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more food to sell in his shop.

loans.name: Mbissane

texts.fr: L'emprunteur est un homme marié, père de cinq enfants.Il exerce l'agriculture notamment la culture d'arachide et de mil;Il achète également des céréales qu'il stock avant de les revendre pendant les périodes ou l'offre devient faible sur le marché. Cette diversité d'activités lui permet d'entretenir sa famille et d'aider ses proches parents.A l'approche des récoltes, il sollicite un pret de 500000F pour acheter de l'achide, du mil et des haricots pour les stocker. Son ambition est de construire un grand magasin de stockage de produits céréaliers.
texts.en:
This borrower is married and the father of five children. He works in agriculture, specifically, he grows groundnuts and millet. He also buys cereals which he stores before reselling them at times when supply in the market is low. Diversifying his activities allows him to support his family and close relatives. 

As the harvest is approaching, he is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs to buy groundnuts, haricot beans and millet for storage. His goal is to build a large warehouse to store cereals.

loans.use: to buy groundnuts, millet and haricot beans.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 32-years old and she is married with two children. Ruth is a self-employed businesswoman who is sells soft drinks. She has been in this business for about 1 1/2 years and her business hours are from 8 am until 9 pm every day.

Ruth needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, Ruth will hopefully expand her business through purchasing different soft drinks like water, juice, fanta and so on. Ruth will hopefully earn more profits which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more soft drinks.

loans.name: Scholar

texts.en:
Scholar is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school.  She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are for food and school fees.

Scholar has been selling green vegetables and tomatoes in a grocer stall to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation. Scholar dreams of expanding her business to earn more profits and meet her basic needs.

With the 20,000 KES she is requesting, she wants to purchase bundles of vegetables, tomatoes, onions and potatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of vegetables, tomatoes, onions and potatoes.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 17 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Eunice has been working hard to manage her catering business, which delivers hot meals to local families and businesses. 

To help expand her business, Eunice has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy electric stoves, plates, and chairs for her customers, and will help Eunice to generate greater profits and help her siblings go to school. Eunice hopes that in the future she will be able to become a medical doctor. 

Eunice is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Eunice's future prospects by teaching her how to save money.

loans.use: to buy electric stoves, plates, and chairs for her customers

loans.name: Faridah Nabukera's Group

texts.en:
Faridah's group is comprised of 3 hard-working women. Faridah is 21 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past 2 years, Faridah has been working hard to manage her boutique shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Faridah has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for resale, and will help Faridah to generate greater profits and expand her business and take care of her family.  Faridah hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a big boutique shop. 

Faridah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Faridah's future prospects by helping her to improving her business.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale,

loans.name: Janerose

texts.en:
Janerose is a farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya.  She is 45 years old and has been in mixed farming for 20 years.  She currently employs one farmhand.  Her farm produces milk, maize, beans and vegetables. She is married, with 6 children, three of whom are still in school. She does water vending for additional income.

Janerose has made a loan request of 40,000 KES to help her purchase a donkey and a donkey cart. She says this will help boost her water vending business and supply her with water for her vegetables and dairy.  She says the additional income will help her pay for the education of her children.

She says the inadequacy of a water supply is a great limitation for farming in the area.

loans.use: To purchase a donkey and a donkey cart

loans.name: Laila

texts.fr: L'emprunteuse est une femme qui exerce dans le commerce de produits cosmétiques. Elle achète en gros du lait de beauté et des parfums qu'elle revend en détail et à crédit à ses clients.Elle arrive à générer des bénéfices qui lui permettent de prendre en charge sa famille et de satisfaire ses propres bénéfices.Elle sollicite un pret de 300000F pour acheter des caisses de lait de beauté et de parfum. Son ambition est de devenir grossiste.
texts.en: The borrower is a woman who trades in cosmetics. She buys beauty lotions and perfumes on a wholesale basis and then sells them on a retail basis and on credit to her customers. She manages to generate sufficient profits to take care of her family and to satisfy her own needs. She is requesting a loan of 300,000 francs to buy crates of beauty lotions and perfume. Her ambition is to become a wholesaler.

loans.use: to buy crates of beauty lotion and perfume

loans.name: Ngono

texts.en:
Ngono is a married woman with three children who are all grown up. Her husband is a farmer who contributes to the provision of family basic needs. She has a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

She has operated a retail shop for the past thirteen years.  Her clients are her neighbors. She faces a major challenge of customers not paying their debts when she sells to them on credit. She dreams of expanding her business into wholesale.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase two sacks of beans, bags of maize flour for her business. She decided to join Yehu to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of beans, bags of maize flour for her business.

loans.name: Kenneddy

texts.en: Kenneddy is a hardworking businessman, aged 40. He is married and blessed with four children, all of whom attend school. For the last two years, he has been operating a retail shop to support his family. He also does farming. He has employed one person to help him to manage the business. In the next 5 years, he wants to establish a wholesale business. His dream is to buy a piece of land. He is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy sugar and cooking fat for resale.

loans.use: To buy sugar and cooking fat

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with five children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a fresh water sales business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase a water pump for her water distribution business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump for her water distribution business.

loans.name: Herbert

texts.en:
Herbert is 29 years old and lives in the town of Mubende in Uganda. For the past two years, Herbert has been working hard to manage his small shop, which sells different kinds of shoes. 

To help expand his business, Herbert has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more pairs of shoes for resale, and will help Herbert to generate greater profits and pay for houses that he is building. Herbert hopes that in the future he will be able to open up a another shop in the neighboring town. 

Herbert is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Herbert who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase shoes to resell

loans.name: Odgerel

texts.en:
Odgerel is a 39-year-old widow who lives with her two sons, ages 6 and 16, in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent.  Their ger is located in the outer ger district of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia, in an area without basic infrastructure. Both of her sons attend the local secondary school.

From 1994 to 2004, Odgerel operated an ice cream selling business.  Since 2009, she has been operating a grocery selling business at the largest outdoor market in Mongolia.  She purchases her products from other wholesale suppliers. 

Autumn is very high shopping season in our country, so every entrepreneur such as Odgerel needs more products to sell. For this reason, she is requesting a loan for 2,500,000 MNT (Mongolian Tugriks) to purchase grocery products to sell in her small stall. Furthermore, she wishes to expand her business and increase her working capital.

loans.use: buy grocery products to sell

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose's Group is comprised of 4 hardworking women. Rose is 21 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past 2 years, Rose has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sugar and soap for resale, and will help Rose generate greater profits and help pay school fees for her child. Rose hopes that in the future she will be able to own the biggest shop in town. 

Rose is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Rose's future prospects by helping to teach her how to save money.

loans.use: to buy more sugar and soap to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy men's and women's clothing, cosmetics, and 50 pairs of shoes

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is a 33-year-old hardworking business man. He is married and blessed with three children. For the last four years, he has been selling clothes to earn a living. He has employed one person to help him manage the business. In the next 5 years, he wants to have a permanent business premise. His dream is to establish a wholesale business. He is requesting for a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy trousers for resale.

loans.use: To buy trousers to resell

loans.name: Mesaid

texts.en:
Mesaid is married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. They live in a house that they own which has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

With the Kshs 10,000 she is requesting, Mesaid wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat, oil and beans. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: buy wheat flour, cooking fat, oil and beans

loans.name: Mti-Pesa Group

texts.en:
Eliaika, who is in her late 30s, is married and has four children, three of whom go to school. She has been selling clothes door-to-door for one year now.  She works from 8 a.m to 6 p.m daily and is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be Eliaika's 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increase her stock of different types of clothes and has paid back her loan successfully. She wants a new loan to increase and buy the latest fashion for a good selling. Her dream is to one day be able to buy a car and to build a house.

Eliaika will share this loan with her loan group "Mti-pesa" which has a total of 16 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: buy clothes to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy basic materials and supplies for shoemaking, such as leather and patent leather

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy various products and condiments

loans.name: Bidhala

texts.en:
Bidhala is a married woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, Bidhala has been operating a mat weaving business and a coconut sales business to earn a living. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Bidhala dreams of expanding her business in the future to meet her customers' needs.

With this loan for Kshs 20,000, Bidhala wants to purchase palm leaves for use as mat weaving materials for her business. She joined Yehu Microfinance to access loans to boost her living standards.

loans.use: buy palm leaves to weave mats

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw materials such as wood and supplies for making new designs

loans.name: Sibanga Shg Group

texts.en:
Samwel is the facilitator of Sibanga SHG group. Samwel and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Samwel and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Samwel takes care of three children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Samwel had an excellent maize yield harvesting 7 bags on 3/4 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Samwel was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on 3/4 acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Samwel will educate his children and save for future use.

In 2012, the members of Sibanga SHG group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize

Picture
In the photograph, Samwel is pictured together with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy hair extensions and cosmetics

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is married and blessed with two children. For the last nine years, he has been selling clothes to earn a living. He has managed to boost his business with previous loans from Faulu Kenya. So far, he has employed one person in his business. He hopes to grow his business and become financially stable in the future. With this loan for 70,000 Kenyan shillings, he wants to buy more shirts for resale.

loans.use: buy shirts to resell

loans.name: Mahougnon De Hevie Group

texts.fr: MAHOUGNON DE HEVIE est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier au Bénin. La représentante du groupe, Marie (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 43 ans et vit dans une ville du Bénin. Marie est mariée à un menuisier du nom de Robert. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Marie vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Marie n'a jamais été à l'école. Depuis environs trois ans, Marie mène comme activité la vente des céréales (maïs et haricot)et de la farine de manioc. Marie s’approvisionne au Bénin. C’est la première fois que Marie et les autres membres du groupe MAHOUGNON DE HEVIE sollicitent l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue de renforcer leur fonds de roulement et leur activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle.
texts.en:
MAHOUGNON DE HEVIE is a group of three persons whose members reside in the same district in Benin. Marie, the group's representative (whose hand is raised in the photo) is 43 years old and lives in a city in Benin. She is married to a woodworker by the name of Robert. They have three children, all in school in their care. She lives together with her husband and children. The couple jointly ensure the different household expenses are covered. For about three years, Marie has been running a business selling grain (corn and beans) and cassava flour. She gets her supplies in Benin. 

This is the first time that Marie and the other members of the group MAHOUGNON DE HEVIE have requested financial support from ALIDé with the aim of bolstering their working capital and their business and responding better to the requirements of their customers.

loans.use: to buy sacks of corn, beans, and cassava flour

loans.name: Nakitanga Group

texts.en:
Annah is the facilitator of the Nakitanga group. Annah and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Annah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Annah takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Annah had an excellent maize yield harvesting 16 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Annah was only able to harvest 12 bags of maize on 3 acres of land.

With income from maize sales, Annah will educate her children, ensure food security, and build a house.

In 2012, the members of Nakitanga group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize

Annah is pictured with her group members above. Moses' wife is standing in for him in this photo.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past three years, Mwanamisi has operated a grocery shop business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation in her business. Mwanamisi dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With this loan for Kshs 20,000,  Mwanamisi wants to purchase bundles of green vegetables, fruits, maize flour and potatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: buy vegetables, fruits, and flour

loans.name: Dieu Est Grand Group

texts.fr: DIEU EST GRAND est un groupe constitué de trois  personnes et dont la représentante(celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) se nomme Germaine. Les membres du groupe sont de la même famille. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement,ce groupe sollicite pour la troisième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Germaine est âgée de 28 ans et est mariée à Félicien un couturier. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge.  Germaine a très peu fréquenté l’école. Pour satisfaire ses besoins et ceux de sa famille, Germaine mène comme activité la vente des savons indigènes. Germaine exerce cette activité depuis près de dix ans ; ce qui lui permet ensemble avec son mari, d’assurer les diverses charges de la famille.Germaine s’approvisionne dans l'un des plus grands marchés du Bénin. Ce troisième prêt permettra certainement à Germaine et à l'ensemble du groupe DIEU EST GRAND, de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en:
DIEU EST GRAND is a group comprised of three persons whose representative (the one with her hand raised in the photo) is called Germaine. The group members are from the same family. With the goal of increasing their working capital, this group is requesting a loan for a third time from ALIDé. 

Germaine is 28 years old and married to Félicien, a clothier. They have five children who are all in school and in their care. She has had very little schooling. To provide for herself and her family, she has a business selling native soaps. She has been in this business for nearly ten years, and it enables her along with her husband to ensure the diverse family expenses are covered. She gets her supplies from one of the large markets in Benin. 

This third loan will surely allow Germaine and her whole group DIEU EST GRAND to  boost their business and to increase their customer base and their revenues.

loans.use: to buy native soaps

loans.name: C4718 Dukore B Group

texts.en:
Julius is 29 years old and is single.  He is the leader of the group called "Dukore B".  Julius is the one in the picture who raises his hand.  He is commonly known for cooking food in his restaurant. Julius has been in this business for about three years and the business hours are from 5 am to 10 pm every day.

Julius and his team have requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, this team will expand its business by purchasing equipments to be used in the restaurant. If successful, Julius and his team will hopefully to earn more profits, which in turn will allow them to keep reinvesting for better financial stability. In addition to that, they will continue improving  their families' lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy equipments for his restaurant.

loans.name: Maneno

texts.en:
Maneno is a married man with two children who are too young for school. His wife is a farmer who contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. He has a house with neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food for his family and transportation. 

He has operated a coconut-selling business for the past ten months; his potential clients are people in the local area. He faces a major challenge of theft. He dreams of owning a shop.

With the loan of Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase coconuts to sell. He decided to join Yehu because it helps him expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.fr:
Mwanajuma is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children. 

Mwanajuma has operated a food café business for the past ten years, selling at the quarry site to miners in the area. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding her business to become self reliant in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of beans, rice, wheat flour, cooking fat oil and utensils. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.
texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children. 

Mwanajuma has operated a café business for the past ten years, selling at the quarry site to miners in the area. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding her business to become self-reliant in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of beans, rice, wheat flour, cooking fat and utensils. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of beans, rice, wheat flour, cooking fat and utensils.

loans.name: Esha

texts.en:
Esha is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a firewood-selling business, selling from home to her neighbors. In addition she also operates a vegetable stall which provides another source of income. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of expanding her business and becoming self-reliant in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of firewood and sacks of green vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood and sacks of green vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Tajy Poty Group

texts.es:
La formación del presente comité se formo gracias a una de las miembros, la cual contacto con sus amigas y vecinas del cual surge el comité denominado Tajy Poty. Actualmente el grupo está integrado por 18 mujeres, las cuales se encuentran en el. Es un grupo que se destaca en el barrio por ser muy unidas solidarias y responsables entre ellas, las mismas realizan labores de incentivos y ayudan en su comunidad con las tareas sociales.
Una de las miembros es la señora Zully, ella se dedica a la venta de prendas de todo tipo, como ser remeras, camisas, y otros. Comenta que gracias a su trabajo ella ha podido salir adelante y darle un mejor estilo de vida a su familia.
Solicita el crédito para la compra de prendas, con lo cual podrá cumplir con los pedidos de sus clientes.
texts.en:
This group was formed thanks to one of the members who contacted her friends and neighbors, and that’s how this group called Tajy Poty came about. 

Tajy Poty now has 18 members among them. This is a group that stands out in their neighborhood for being a responsible team that cares about one another, and at the same time they have work incentives and they help with community projects.

One of the members is Zully, who works selling all kinds of garments, such as t-shirts, shirts, and other items. She says that thanks to her work she can get ahead and give her family a better quality of life.

She is asking for this loan in order to purchase clothing, in order to fulfill her customers' orders.

loans.use: to buy clothing for later resale

loans.name: Musemwa C Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Western Kenya, and the farmers of Musemwa group!  Jenifer is the facilitator of the Musemwa C group. Jenifer and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jenifer and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Jenifer takes care of three children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Jenifer had an excellent maize yield harvesting 9 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jenifer was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Jenifer will educate her children and put aside savings for future use.

In 2012, the members of Musemwa group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize

In the photograph, Jenifer is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Osiris Antonia

texts.es: Osiris aunque su negocio principal es la lavandería,encontró otra fuente de ingreso rápido en la venta de cárnicos con los cuales le ha aumentado la rotación de su dinero, por eso,  con su anterior credikiva compró carne, queso y pescado, y de ahí invierte en lavadoras nuevas, así que  quiere continuar incrementando este negocio y por eso acude a un nuevo credikiva, con el cual comprará en mayor volumen productos cárnicos, porque son los que han incrementado su clientela y trabaja mediante pedidos. Su mensaje a los financiadores de Kiva es el siguinte: "Gracias por la labor que vienen realizando con los microempresarios, deseo que al igual que a mi me apoyan, continuen patrocinando a los demás personas que tambien tienen negocios".
texts.en:
Athough her principal business is washing clothes, she found another source of quick income with which she has increased the rotation of her money and Osiris bought meat, cheese and fish with her previous KIva loan and invested it in new washing machines. She wants to continue increasing it and this is why she is asking for a new KIva loan. 

She plans to buy a larger amount of meat products, because she has increased her customer base and this is what her clients have been ordering. Her message to the KIva lenders is the following, "Thanks for the work you are doing with micro lending. I hope that you continue to help me, and other people who have businesses."

loans.use: Purchase two washing machines to expand her business

loans.name: Jose Aquilino

texts.es:
José, se decidio por un nuevo prestamo porque esta iniciando un nuevo cultivo, ya que necesita para comprar herbicidas para las plagas, abono y semilla para sembrar,  para que sus cosechas sean mejores este año y aumente sus ingresos. El prestamo anterior le ayudo muchisimo y esta muy agradecido ya que la alimentacion de la familia depende de él.
Su aspiración es tener lo necesario para su familia, darle una mejor educación a su hijo.
texts.en:
José is asking for this new loan because he is starting a new crop, and he needs to buy herbicides for the pests, and fertilizer, and seeds to sow in order to have better crops this year and increase his income. His last loan helped him very much and he is grateful because he earns the daily bread for his family.

His dream is to provide for his family's needs and to give his child a better education.

loans.use: to purchase herbicides, fertilizer, and seeds

location.town: San Rafael de Oriente, San Miguel

loans.name: Nabusoba Group

texts.en:
Jacklyne is the facilitator of Nabusoba group. Jacklyne and her group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
	
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important farming inputs to distribute to Jacklyne and her group during Kenya’s next  planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture  package, which includes training, reliable input supply, such as fertilizer, seeds, credit and insurance.

Jacklyne takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre fund in order to get money and educate her children and also to buy livestock. In the recent 2011 season, Jacklyne had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 16 bags on a one-acre piece of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jacklyne was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on one acre of land.

With the income from maize sales, Jacklyne intends to buy livestock and also to get food for her family.

In 2012 members of Nabusoba group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Wakulima Group

texts.en:
Nancy is the facilitator of the Wakulima group. Nancy and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Nancy and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Nancy takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Nancy had a very good maize yield harvesting 8 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Nancy was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on ½ an acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Nancy will educate her children and ensure food security for her family.

In 2012, the members of Wakulima group will each plant maize on plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph, Nancy is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: C13013 Dukorerehamwe Group

texts.en:
Jacqueline, a 41-year-old married mother of three children between the ages of 10 and 17, is the president of a group called "Dukorerehamwe". This is her fifth successful year in the business of selling charcoal, vegetables, and fruit. She works every day from 7 a.m. until 8 p.m.

Jacqueline and her team have requested a loan to purchase more charcoal, vegetables, and fruit to sell. By using this loan, Jacqueline and her team expect to earn more profits which, in turn, will allow each member of the group to start saving as well as building a better future for their families.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal, vegetables, and fruit to sell.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria es una microempresaria, su negocio se llama Variedades Maria, donde vende diferentes productos. Su negocio esta ubicado en su casa desde donde vende sus productos a los clientes que van a comprar y tambien de modo ambulante, de esta manera ella promueve su negocio. Maria esta recibiendo su cuarto prestamo, el cual piensa invertirlo en la compra de Ropas, calzados, cosmeticos, ropa interiores, entre otras. Maria comenzo su negocio despues de adquirir su primer prestamo en Esperanza, logrando superarse y establecerse poco a poco su negocio.

Maria es madre de 2 hijos, a los cuales ha criado con mucho esfuerzo y trabajo. Siempre ha trabajado y realizado diferentes negocios con la finalidad de ayudar con los ingresos de su familia, y poder cubrir sus necesidades, como toda madre desea ver a sus hijos, convertidos en personas de bien, profesionales y que puedan tener sus propias familias. 

El reto mas importante al igual que su sueño es poder establecer un local para su negocio, donde pueda tener una pequeña tienda por departamentos.
texts.en:
Maria is a micro-entrepreneur. Her business is named Variedades Maria; she sells a variety of products. Her business is located in her home where she sells her products to her customers who come to shop there. She also works as a traveling vendor, thus promoting her business. Maria is receiving her fourth loan, which she plans to invest in the purchase of clothing, shoes, cosmetics, and undergarments, among other items. Maria began her business after obtaining her first loan from Esperanza, managing to better herself and establish her business little by little.

Maria is the mother of two children, who she has raised with a lot of effort and hard work. She has always worked and been involved in different businesses in order to help with the family income and cover their necessities. Like all mothers, she would like to see her children grow into good professionals so that they can have their own families.

The most important goal, and her dream, is to be able to set up premises for her business, where she can have a small department store.

loans.use: to purchase clothing, shoes, cosmetics, etc.

loans.name: Peshency

texts.en:
Peshency is a widowed woman with three children; two of her children attend school and the third is grown. She has a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children. 

She has operated a cafe for the past three years; her clients are neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality: when the cost of food is high, there is low demand. She dreams of establishing a restaurant in the future.

With the loan of Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and cooking oil for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Kisiwa B Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is the facilitator of the Kisiwa B group. Beatrice and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Beatrice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Beatrice takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to attain food security for her family and access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, Beatrice had a very good maize yield harvesting 8 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Beatrice was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Beatrice will educate her children and save for future use.

In 2012, the members of Kisiwa B group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

Beatrice is pictured above with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Naida Esther

texts.es: Naida  de 71 años de edad  se dedica a la venta de mercancías variadas;  ella es casada y tiene 6 hijos en las edades de 40 a 50 años.; al principio vendía gaseosas y cervezas, pero gradualmente su capital de trabajo se ha incrementado, apoyada mediante 6 financiamientos que ha realizado en la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con ellos ha logrado convertir su negocio en una variedad o miscelánea con vitrinas bien surtidas. En la actualidad se prepara para su primer credikiva con el cual comprará cosméticos, accesorios femeninos, para venderlos,  en este fin de año que se acerca con muchas ofertas de sus proveedores  y ella  quiere aprovecharlas. Igualmente   sus clientes empiezan a tener en sus manos bonificaciones primas etc y a comprar en mayor volumen. Su sueño es continuar progresando y tener muchas satisfacciones, las  que encuentra en la actividad que desempeña, pues sus hijos ya están grandes  e independientes.
texts.en: Naida is 71 years old. She sells varied merchandise. She is married and has 6 children ranging in age from 40 to 50 years old. At first she sold soft drinks and beer but gradually her working capital has increased with the support of 6 loans she has taken out with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. With them, she has been able to convert her business into a variety store with display cases full of different things. At present, she is preparing for her first Kiva loan with which she will buy cosmetics, and women's accessories to sell. At the end of this year there are going to be a lot of deals from suppliers and she wants to take advantage of that. Her customers are also going to begin to have their bonuses on hand and will buy in greater volume. Her dream is to continue progressing and have a lot of satisfying experiences. She finds these in the work she does, since her children are grown and independent.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics, and women's accessories to sell.

loans.name: Edigina

texts.en: Edigina is taking another Kiva loan for 85,000 KES to purchase a motorcycle to venture into the transport business. She dreams of expanding her business and purchasing a matatu (motor vehicle) for the transport business.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle for her transport business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a copier, beverages and snacks to meet the demand of nearby schools.

loans.name: Umoja Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Western Kenya and the farmers of Umoja SHG group!  Vitalis is the facilitator of the Umoja SHG group. Vitalis and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Vitalis and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Vitalis takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family, and to have additional profit for school fees.  In the recent 2011 season, Vitalis had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 12 ½ bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Vitalis was only able to harvest 3 ½ bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Vitalis will educate his children, and make improvements upon his house.

In 2012, the members of Umoja SHG group will each plant between ½ and 2 acres of maize.

In the photograph above, Vitalis is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Magdaline

texts.en:
Magdaline is requesting another Kiva loan of 40,0000 KES to purchase more goats.  She will fatten and sell them at a higher price. 

She dreams of expanding her business opportunities in the future.

loans.use: to purchase goats to fatten and sale.

loans.name: Mulembe Yg A Group

texts.en:
Moses is the facilitator of the Mulembe YG group. Moses and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Moses and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Moses takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and good harvests from the neighbors and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Moses had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 12 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Moses was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on a ½  acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Moses will educate his children.

In 2012, the members of Mulembe YG group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

In the photograph above, Moses is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Eternel Plus Group

texts.en:
Mudilawe is the leader of the “Eternel Plus” group consisting of up of 10 members.  They are firmly united to request loans from the MFI (Micro-Finance Institution) HOPE RDC so they can develop their businesses.

Mudilawe’s main business is selling foam rubber mattresses.  He has years of experience and works hard with good management skills.  His goal is to open a mattress shop. 

He would also like to achieve financial independence through his business.  Mudilawe earns $50 per week. 

Mudilawe is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having eight previous correctly repaid loans.  He will increase his stock of products with his next loan by buying more mattresses and reselling them at a profit.   

Mudilawe, age 41, is married and has five children, ages 18 months to 14 years old.  Four attend school.

loans.use: to increase his stock of mattresses and to resell them at a profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard is taking another Kiva loan of 40,000 KES to add on his stock at his retail shop.  He'll purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, beans and rice.  He dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of maize flour, rice and wheat flour for resale.

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es: Luz Marina, de 55 años vive en el municipio de San Jacinto donde tiene un negocio de confecciones, con los cuales han salido adelante su familia, pues en condición de separada ha duplicado sus esfuerzos para que sus hijos lograran ser profesionales de bien, meta que alcanzó.  Como toda mujer en San Jacinto se dedicó a las artesanías  inicialmente, pero no sintió muy productivo este negocio para ella, decidió enfocarse en la confección haciendo énfasis en la línea masculina que es muy poco común. Sus clientes se ubican en las ciudades de Cartagena, Bogotá y Barranquilla pues en estas ciudades les gusta el trabajo que hace Luz Marina, pues le agrega valor a ellos mediante las aplicaciones bordadas que les aplica. Su credikiva es el segundo financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo con el cual comprará  accesorios de modistería, como encajes, botones, cintas, hebillas y apliques; así mismo invertirá en bisutería para surtir el local que tiene, donde actualmente  habita y posicionarse en su mercado objeto.
texts.en:
Luz Marina is 55 and lives in the municipality of San Jacinto.  She has a sewing business, through which she has helped her family get ahead. The fact that she is separated, has doubled her efforts to see her children have good professions; a goal she has reached.

Like every woman in San Jacinto, she did handicrafts initially; but she didn't feel very productive in this business. She decided to focus on making clothing, with emphasis on men's wear, which is uncommon to do.  Her customers live in the cities of Cartagena, Bogotá, and Barranquilla, as in these cities they like the work that Luz Marina does. She adds value by means of the embroidered appliqués that she sews on them.  

This is her second loan from Fundación Santo Domingo, and she will use it to buy sewing accessories, such as laces, buttons, ribbons, buckles and appliqués; also to buy costume jewellery to stock her shop (where she currently lives), and to position herself in relation to her target market.

loans.use: To buy sewing accessories, such as laces, buttons, ribbons, buckles and appliqués; and to buy costume jewellery to stock her shop.

loans.name: Hugo

texts.es: Hugo, de 38 años, convive con Encarnación, su esposa. Ambos tienen 3 hijos: Yelsi, Nicol y Paola. En unión familiar ellos viven en su casa propia ubicada en la comunidad de Sanchirio el palomar (selva central peruana). La vida de está familia se centra en Dios, junto a su esposa cultivan en sus hijos la fe. Aquello que les ayuda en el trabajo que realizan. La siembra de café y plátano, es su actividad económica. Ya tiene 8 años dedicándose a ello, y según afirma lo que más le gusta a él es poder limpiar su terreno agrícola, “me divierte, quitar la maleza de la tierra”, menciona. Cada 15 días viaja a la ciudad de La Merced, donde vende los plátanos que cosecha, pero su producción de café, los vende a los acopiadores, que constantemente visitan sus cultivos. A Hugo le falta capital, para mejorar la calidad de sus plantaciones; ya que invierte en los estudios de sus hijos. Pero está juntando dinero para abrir un negocio de comestibles; con el que piensa generar nuevos ingresos y así, invertir mayor dinero en la agricultura. Él pertenece al banco comunal “Buenos Aires” y este es el cuarto crédito con MFP, donde  gusta del trabajo que desarrolla junto a su banco comunal, pues en este corto tiempo pudo lograr mejoras en sus cultivos. Por ello promete ser puntual en sus cuotas.  Hugo de recibir su apoyo; comprará fertilizantes naturales para sus cafetales, ya que quiere mantener la calidad de los mismos, para la próxima cosecha.
texts.en:
Hugo is 38 years old and lives with Encarnacion, his wife. They have 3 children: Yelsi, Nicol, and Paola. As a family unit, they live in their own house in the community of Sanchirio el Palomar (in Peru's central jungle). Family life centers on God. Hugo and his wife cultivate faith among their children. This helps them in the work they do, sowing coffee and plantains, which is their economic activity. They have been dedicated to this for 8 years. They say that what they like most about this is being able to clear their agricultural land. “I enjoy removing weeds from the land,” says Hugo. 

Every 15 days he visits the city of La Merced where he sells harvested plantains, but his coffee production is sold to buyers who constantly visit his fields. Hugo lacks capital to improve the quality of his plantations, since he is investing in his children's studies. But he is accumulating money to open a grocery store, with which he hopes to generate new income and thus, to invest more money in agriculture. 

Hugo belongs to the “Buenos Aires” (Good Breezes) communal bank and this is his 4th loan with MFP, where he likes the work they do together. In a short time he has been able to make improvements in his crops. That's why he promises to be punctual in his payments. With this loan, Hugo will buy natural fertilizer for his coffee groves, since he wants to maintain their quality for the coming harvest.

loans.use: to buy sacks of fertilizer for his coffee groves.

loans.name: Mawenzi Group

texts.en:
Chilala has run a video library business for one year. He works from 9:00a.m to midnight and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be his first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He will use the money to increase his library stock.  His dream is to be an agent for M-Pewa and Tigo Pesa (electric money transfer).

He will share this loan with his loan group called "Mawenzi" which consists of 16 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: to increase his library stock.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Edilma Maria

texts.es: Edilma D. 56 años D. edad, es madre D. 3 hijos vive en la ciudad D. Cartagena, donD. se dedica a la actividad D. comerciante, ella venD. productos alimenticios como dulces y mercancía variada por encargo, que distribuye cliente a cliente en el barrio donD. habita y en los alrededores D. este;  Antes D. iniciar su vida comercial fue empleada del servicio doméstico y poco a poco ahorró hasta lograr tener su primer capital e independizarse mediante este negocio. Sus ventas son a crédito y sus compras las hace D. contado; hoy se prepara para comprar más volumen D. mercancías, pues debe  atender el último trimestre del año,  que son épocas D. buenas ventas. Esto es lo que justamente hará con su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, comprará productos D. dulcería para surtir su chaza y cosméticos, accesorios etc. Su meta más adelante es tener su propia casa y adecuar allí un local bien construido. Esta es la razón por la cual su visión D. negocio no es otra que crecer.
texts.en:
56-year-old Edilma is a mother of three children.  She lives in the city of Cartagena where she works as a saleswoman.  She sells food products such as sweet treats and also sells a range of merchandise to order.  She distributes her merchandise customer to customer in her neighborhood and surrounding areas.  Before she started her life as a saleswoman, Edilma worked as a maid.  She gradually saved up until she'd gathered together her first lot of capital and then started working for herself in this business.  She makes her sales on credit and buys with cash.  She is preparing to buy a larger volume of merchandise as she needs to have enough stock to deal with the final quarter of the year which is a period when she makes good sales.  

Edilma will use her Kiva loan, which is the first loan she has received from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, to buy sweet treats with which to stock her street stall, and also to buy cosmetics and accessories.  Her goal for the future is to own her own home and to set up a well-constructed sales location there.  This is why her vision for her business is simply to grow it.

loans.use: to buy sweet treats to stock her street stall, and to buy cosmetics and accessories

loans.name: Mauricio Alexander

texts.es:
Mauricio es un joven ecuatoriano de 24 años de edad nacido en la ciudad de Quito, vive al sur de la ciudad en el barrio "La Villaflora", un sector pintoresco muy transitado y comercial.

Es padre soltero, tiene un hijo menor. Hace algunos años trabajó para un fotógrafo de quien aprendió sobre el negocio de filmación y fotografía de eventos y fiestas. Hace tres años puso su propio local de organización de fiestas y filmación. El negocio le ha ido muy bien y quiere invertir en otro local para de esta manera expandir su negocio y tener mejores ganancias. Piensa abrir un local en una avenida principal del sur de Quito y de esta manera tendrá mayor clientela.

Nos comenta que el se considera muy joven pero con muchas ganas de salir adelante con este negocio; trabaja todo el día e incluso en la noche y fines de semana, todo depende de la demanda de sus clientes. Sueña con poder ampliarse a otras ciudades y así convertirse en un gran empresario.
texts.en:
Mauricio is a young Ecuadorian 24-year-old, born in the city of Quito.  He lives south of the city in the neighborhood, "La Villaflora," a picturesque area that is well traveled and commercial.

Mauricio is a single parent and has a young son. A few years ago he worked for a photographer from whom he learned about the business of filming and photography of events and parties. Three years ago he put together his own business of party planning and filming. The business has gone very well and he wants to invest in another location to expand his business and have better returns.  Mauricio is thinking of opening a store on a main road south of Quito and thus will have more customers.

Mauricio says that he is considered very young but he is eager to go forward with this business.  He works all day and even at night and on weekends, depending on customer demand. He dreams of being able to expand to other cities and thus become an great entrepreneur.

loans.use: to open another branch of a party planning business.

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es: Ricardo, de 25 años vive con Maylem, su esposa. Ambos tienen 2 hermosos hijos: Yero y Alexis. En unión familiar ellos viven en su casa propia, ubicada en la comunidad de Sanchirio del Palomar (selva central peruana). El trabajo constante es su principal característica. Pues es un padre de familia responsable; desde temprano trabaja en sus terrenos agrícolas, sus principales cultivos constan de plátanos y café. Los que según menciona, le generan buenos ingresos, ya que sus cosechas en campañas agrícolas son los mejores de la zona, este logro lo consiguió a base de capacitaciones para conseguir un buen grano de café. Mientras que sus frutos de plátanos, le proporcionan estabilidad; pues cada 15 días, después de la cosecha los comercializa en el mercado central de su ciudad. Por ello más adelante desea comprar más terrenos agrícolas, en las que pueda aplicar todo lo que aprendió y así tener cada día mejores cultivos; tanto en cantidad y calidad. Él pertenece al banco comunal “Buenos Aires” y este es el tercer crédito con MFP, donde saldrá adelante junto a su asociación, pues son personas responsables y solidarias. Por ello promete ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas. Ricardo después de la cosecha piensa renovar sus plantaciones, con cafetales nuevos. De recibir su apoyo, comprará 2 mil plantitas de café y fertilizantes naturales para que sus sembríos sean todo un éxito.
texts.en:
Ricardo is 25 years old and lives with Maylem, his wife. They have 2 beautiful children: Yero and Alexis. They live in their own house in the community of Sanchirio del Palomar (in the central Peruvian jungle). Ricardo's principal trait is constant work. He is a responsible father of a family; from early hours he works in his agricultural fields. 

His principal crops are plantains and coffee. It bears mentioning that they generate good income, since his harvests are the best in the zone in agricultural campaigns. Ricardo's achievement is based on his training in how to produce a good coffee bean. Meanwhile, his plantains give them stability, as every 15 days, following harvest, he sells them in the central market of his city. For that reason, later on, Ricardo wants to buy more agricultural land, in which he can apply all he has learned and thus, have better crops each day, in both quantity and quality.

Ricardo belongs to the “Buenos Aires” (Good Breezes) communal bank and this is his 3rd loan with MFP, and he expects to advance with the association, since they are responsible persons with solidarity. He promises to be punctual in his payments. 

After the harvest, Ricardo plans to renew his fields, with new coffee groves. Upon receiving the loan, he will buy 2,000 young coffee plants and natural fertilizer so that his groves will be a complete success.

loans.use: to buy 2,000 coffee plants and sacks of fertilizer for his coffee groves

loans.name: Judith

texts.es:
Judith, de 23 años, convive con Ángel, su esposo. Producto de su amor, nació Luz Clarita, de 3 años. En unión familiar ellos viven en su casa propia, ubicada en la comunidad de Sanchirio del Palomar (selva central peruana).
Ella es una mujer valerosa y a pesar de su corta edad, afronta los retos con normalidad. Hace 2 años comenzó a sembrar en terrenos alquilados y uno propio que compró hace algunos meses. Sus principales sembríos constan de café, plátano y maíz híbrido. Los que con mucho esfuerzo y trabajo mantiene. A diferencia de los demás, ella tiene que trabajar el doble para costear los gastos de producción y los de arrendamiento de su terreno agrícola. Aunque ya adquirió uno, no se conforma, pues sabe que con trabajo y ahorro podrá comprar más. Además desea mejorar sus cultivos, ya que los compradores que visitan la zona; ofrecen mejores pagos de acuerdo a la calidad del grano y fruto. Por eso luchará para el éxito de su negocio. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Buenos Aires” y este es el cuarto crédito con MFP, donde se siente dichosa por el apoyo que se dan mutuamente. Además agradece al apoyo recibido, por ello promete ser puntual en sus cuotas. Judith de recibir su apoyo; invertirá el dinero solicitado en la compra de fertilizantes naturales para que sus cultivos se fortalezcan.
texts.en:
Judith, 23, lives with her husband, Ángel, and their 3-year-old daughter, Clarita, in their own house in Sanchirio del Palomar (the central Peruvian jungle).

She is a valiant women who despite her youth, confronts challenges as normal events.  2 years ago she began to plant on rented fields and one of her own that she bought some months previously.  Her main crops are coffee, plantains, and hybrid corn and she works them with a lot of effort.
As different from other farmers, she has to work twice as hard to cover the production expenses and the rental of the fields.
